120165 120165 S0926-860X(25)00066-3 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120165 The Authors Fig. 1 [a] SEM and [b] brightfield STEM micrographs of CB-H. [c] Specific surface area and Raman ID/IG ratio of the carbon black supports functionalized at different HNO3 oxidation and annealing temperatures. [d] N2 physisorption isotherms at −196 °C of the different carbon black supports and [e] N2 physisorption isotherms shifted on the y-axis for comparability, fixing the N2 uptake at a relative pressure of p/p0 0.03 at 0 mmol g−1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TPD-MS [a] CO2 and [b] CO emission profiles of the carbon black supports, including the decomposition ranges of the most prominent surface oxides. [c] Oxygen weight loading as determined by TPD-MS and surface coverage of the different supports. Quantification of [d] CO2 and [e] CO emitting surface groups obtained by curve fitting of the TPD-MS CO2 and CO emission profiles. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 [a] Particle size distribution of unsupported, colloidal CoO NP. [b] Brightfield STEM micrograph of unsupported CoO NP. [c] High angular annular dark field (HAADF) STEM image of pristine Co/CB-H. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 [a] H2-TPR or the pristine Co/CB catalysts (20 mL min−1 7 vol% H2 in Ar, heating rate 5 °C min−1). [b] Reduction of Co/CB-H at atmospheric pressure (10 °C min−1 to 350 °C in a flow of 0.5 mL min−1 25 vol% H2 in He) monitored by in situ XANES. Linear combination fitting (LCF) employing Co, CoO and Co3O4 standards was used to determine the relative fractions of Co species. [c] Development of the Co0 fraction of the Co/CB catalysts as followed by in situ XANES LCF analysis and the corresponding relative H2O and CO2 concentration in the effluent gas as analyzed by online mass spectrometry during catalyst reduction. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 HAADF-STEM images of [a] pristine Co/CB-H, [b] reduced and passivated Co/CB-H [c] spent (after 115 h FTS) and passivated Co/CB-H, [d] pristine Co/CB-70, (e) reduced/passivated Co/CB-70 and [f] spent/passivated Co/CB-70. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 [a] Average Co0 particle size of the pristine, reduced (1 °C min−1 to 350 °C, 8 h hold, 25 vol% H2 in Ar) and passivated as well as spent(115 h FTS)/passivated Co/CB catalysts. Carbon catalyst supports offer an attractive alternative to traditional oxidic supports for Co-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts, however, weak metal/carbon interactions facilitate catalyst deactivation by cobalt nanoparticle sintering. In this study we investigated the introduction of carbon surface oxides to mitigate cobalt sintering, combining carbon model supports featuring various surface oxide profiles with size-defined, colloidal Co nanoparticles. Carbon surface oxidation was found to effectively suppress cobalt nanoparticle sintering. Employing in situ XRD and XAS, we could show that Co supported on carbon featuring surface carbonyls/quinones displays low reducibility and forms disordered, polycrystalline Co0 nanoparticles, which are associated with poor FTS performance. In contrast, Co on supports occupied by carboxylic acids were easily reducible and formed monocrystalline nanoparticles enabling comparatively high FTS activities. However, despite effectively suppressing Co nanoparticle sintering, carbon surface oxidation was proven detrimental for FTS performance, as Co supported on non-functionalized carbon outperformed all catalysts on oxidized supports. Graphical Abstract Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Carbon supports Carbon surface chemistry Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In a future circular economy, the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) represents a valuable technology to transform syngas obtained from renewable resources to fuels and chemical building blocks [1–5]. A standard catalyst system for FTS is based on supported cobalt nanoparticles, with porous oxidic supports such as γ-Al2O3, SiO2 and TiO2 being most frequently employed [6–8]. Oxidic supports exhibit a high degree of interaction with Co, which impedes catalyst deactivation by nanoparticle sintering[9], but causes low Co reducibility [10] and loss of Co to non-regenerable mixed oxides (e. g. CoxAlyOz [11,12], CoxSiyOz [12]). Attractive alternatives to porous oxides are carbon catalyst supports [13–15], which are inert and do not suffer from the loss of Co to inactive metal/support compounds [12]. In addition, carbon materials exhibit a comparatively low degree of metal/support interaction that facilitates Co reducibility [16,17]. However, this weak of interaction between Co and carbon supports often fails to provide sufficient anchoring to Co nanoparticles, promoting catalyst deactivation by sintering [12,18]. Aiming to optimize metal/carbon interactions, major research efforts were directed at the introduction of oxygen functional groups to the carbon surface, which increase the surface polarity and provide anchoring sites for Co nanoparticles [19–29]. Even when not intentionally introduced by support oxidation, the presence of carbon surface oxides is almost unavoidable, as they may be formed by simple air exposure of the carbon support or during catalyst calcination when using traditional catalyst precursors such as metal nitrates. Thus, a significant fraction of literature reports on the effects of carbon surface oxidation on dispersion and FTS performance of Co/C catalysts concluded that the presence of O functional groups was beneficial for catalyst activity and stability [20,21,23,26,28,29]. However, oxidized and non-oxidized carbon supports are challenging to compare, as impregnation/calcination catalyst synthesis methods yield significantly deviating Co particle size distributions due to the differences in surface polarity. As non-classical Co particle size effects are well-established for FTS [30–32], the disentanglement of carbon support effects from Co particle size effects is thus rendered virtually impossible. In this context, Eschemann et al [24]. and van Deelen et al[19]. compared oxidized and non-oxidized carbons supporting Co nanoparticles with similar size distributions and concluded that carbon surface oxidation does indeed prevent Co nanoparticle sintering, although at the price of a lower FTS activity. Beyond these contradicting literature studies reporting either improved [20,21,23,26,28,29] or impaired [19,24] FTS performance as a consequence of carbon support oxidation, the detailed effects of carbon surface oxides on the active Co phase remain largely in the dark. Besides Co particle size effects, another factor of complication is that all published studies to date investigate non-selectively oxidized carbon supports. As strong oxidants (e. g. HNO3 [19,20,23], H2O2 [21,22]) are applied in all cases, ensembles of multiple oxygen functional groups are introduced to the support surface [33–36]. The effects of carbon surface oxidation on the catalytic performance of Co FTS catalysts established so far in literature are thus ensemble effects, reflecting a superposition of the influence of all individual surface oxides present in the specific ensemble that is studied. In this context, it is important to note that individual carbon surface oxides may exhibit fundamentally different properties, as carboxylic acids are highly acidic while carbonyl groups display a basic character [37–40]. Consequently, it is to be expected that in addition to the mere presence of carbon surface oxides, the composition of the carbon surface oxide ensemble also significantly influences catalytic activity and stability of carbon supported Co FTS catalysts. In this study, we prepared model catalysts by combining carbon supports featuring similar oxygen loading but different surface oxide ensembles with pre-synthesized, colloidal Co nanoparticles with narrow size distribution. By investigating these highly defined catalyst models with comprehensive (in situ) characterization, this study aims to shed light on the effects of various carbon surface oxide compositions on the structure as well as the activity and stability of carbon supported Co FTS catalysts. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials All gases were purchased from Linde AG. Carbon black (Printex® 60) was provided by Orion Engineered Carbons and was used without any further pretreatment. Nitric acid (65 wt%), oleic acid (90 %, technical grade), 1,2-dichlorobenzene (99 %, anhydrous) and dicobalt octacarbonyl (90 %) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. N-hexane and toluene were acquired from Merck, while isopropanol, acetone and 1-octadecene (90 %) were purchased from Fisher Scientific. CoO and Co3O4 powder were acquired from Alfa Aesar. 2.2 Functionalization of carbon black supports In a round-bottomed flask equipped with a reflux condenser, carbon black (CB) was dispersed in 65 wt% HNO3 at a ratio of 25 mLHNO3 g−1 CB. Under magnetic stirring, the dispersion was heated in an oil bath to the desired temperature (70, 95, 120, 140 °C oil bath temperature), which was kept constant for 2 h. After cooling, the oxidized CB was washed with de-ionized water by centrifugation and dried overnight at 100 °C in air. Oxidized CB was subsequently annealed in a vertical tubular furnace, using a quartz reactor of 40 mm internal diameter equipped with a ceramic frit holding the sample and an internal type K thermocouple regulating the furnace temperature. In a flow of 100 mL min−1 Ar, 2 g of CB were heated at a rate of 5 °C min−1 to the desired temperature (330, 530, 650 °C), which was kept constant for 2 h. A pristine, non-oxidized CB sample was heated in a 100 mL min−1 flow of 10 vol% H2 in Ar at a rate of 10 °C min−1 to 950 °C, which was kept constant for 1 h. This sample was used as a reference with minimal O loading, and is subsequently denoted as CB-H. All oxidized or oxidized/annealed support samples, are designated as CB-Toxidation and CB-Toxidation-Tannealing, respectively. 2.3 Co nanoparticle synthesis and attachment For the synthesis and attachment of colloidal Co nanoparticles, procedures by van Deelen et al. were adapted [19,41]. Briefly, 73.5 μL of oleic acid were transferred to a 100 mL three-neck flask connected to a Schlenk line and equipped with reflux condenser, two septa and magnetic stirrer. The oleic acid was degassed under vacuum at 100 °C for 30 min while stirring at 150 rpm. After flushing the system with N2, 7.5 mL dry 1,2-dichlorobenzene was added, and the mixture was heated to 174 °C while stirring at 750 rpm. In a glovebox, 270 mg of dicobalt octacarbonyl was dissolved in 1.5 mL dry 1,2-dichlorobenzene, and rapidly injected into the hot solution of oleic acid in 1,2-dichlorobenzene. The reaction mixture was stirred at 750 rpm for 20 min at 174 °C before quenching in a water bath. After cooling to room temperature, the septa were removed and the N2 flow was stopped, exposing the Co nanoparticles (Co NP) slowly to air by stirring at 650 rpm for 1 h. To purify the Co NP, the dispersion was transferred to a poly-propylene centrifuge tube, which was subsequently filled to a volume of 45 mL with isopropanol. The dispersion was centrifuged for 20 min at 2200 G, after which the supernatant was decanted before re-dispersing the Co NP in 1 mL n-hexane. 40 mL of isopropanol were added, and the washing cycle was repeated three times. After the last washing cycle, the Co NP were re-dispersed in 2 mL toluene and stored in a glass vial. For Co NP deposition, several batches of NP dispersion in toluene were mixed, so that every support was loaded with the same single charge of Co NP’s consisting of multiple mixed individual synthesis batches. For Co NP attachment, 750 mg of CB support was dispersed in 15 mL of 1-octadecene under 400 rpm magnetic stirring for 15 min in a 100 mL three-neck flask connected to a Schlenk line and equipped with reflux condenser and two septa. Under continuous stirring at 400 rpm, 2.4 mL of the Co NP dispersion in toluene were added, and the mixture was degassed by slowly applying vacuum, heating to 100 °C and holding for 30 min. After degassing, the flask was flushed with N2 and heated to 200 °C for 30 min and subsequently left to cool. Upon addition of 20 mL acetone, the suspension was transferred to a 50 mL centrifuge tube, and centrifuged for 5 min at 2500 G. The supernatant was decanted and the Co/CB catalyst was re-dispersed in 2 mL of n-hexane before adding 6 mL of acetone and centrifuging again. This washing cycle was repeated 6 times, before the catalyst samples were dried at 60 °C overnight in a vacuum oven. 2.4 Characterization Nitrogen physisorption was conducted after sample degassing at 200 °C and 0.01 Torr overnight at −196 °C on a Micromeritics Tristar 3020 analyzer. Specific surface areas were determined by the BET method. Raman spectroscopy was executed on a Horiba Jobin Yvon LabRAM HR800 Raman microscope, employing a HeNe laser at a wavelength of 633 nm. Analysis of the Raman spectra by curve-fitting was performed according to Mallet-Ladeira et al [42]. For each sample, at least 5 spectra of different sites were recorded and evaluated. CHNS/O elemental analysis was performed using an Elementar UNICUBE analyzer. The contents of carbon (C), hydrogen (H), nitrogen (N) and sulfur (S) were determined by combusting solid samples at 1050 °C in oxygen, followed by reduction at 850 °C. The resulting gases were separated and quantified using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for N2, CO2, and H2O, and an infrared (IR) detector for SO2. The elemental content of oxygen (O) was determined by pyrolysis in He at 1050 °C, with the produced carbon monoxide detected via TCD. In general, four measurements were taken per sample, with the last three averaged for accuracy. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) was conducted using a Netzsch STA 409 Luxx thermogravimetric balance coupled to a calibrated online mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer Omnistar). Measurements were conducted in a flow of 30 mL min−1 of He, heating the sample to 1000 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1. To quantify carbon surface oxides, CO, CO2 and H2O emission profiles were baseline corrected and fitted using Gaussian profiles following literature procedures (see SI for a detailed fitting procedure) [36,43,44]. Further thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted in a Netzsch STA449 balance, employing a flow of 30 mL min−1 of Ar and a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. Co loading was determined by microwave digestion in aqua regia (Berghof SpeedWave XPERT) followed by microwave plasma excited atomic emission spectroscopy (Agilent 4210, MP-AES). Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was conducted on an Altamira Benchcat analyzer, in which the sample was placed between two quartz wool plugs in a U-shaped quartz reactor and heated in a 20 mL min−1 flow of 7 vol% H2 in Ar at a rate of 5 °C min−1 to 800 °C. The H2 concentration in the effluent gas stream was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) were conducted on a Hitachi SU9000 electron microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 30 kV. Catalyst samples were dispersed in n-hexane by ultra sonication before drop casting on holey carbon coated copper grids. Spent catalyst samples were washed thoroughly with n-hexane before deposition on sample grids. Particle size distributions were determined by manually counting 300–500 particles. A Kratos Analytical Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer was employed for X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using monochromatic Al Kα irradiation (1486.6 eV) operating the anode at 10 kV with an aperture of 700 x 300 μm. The pass energy for surveys was 160 eV, while high-resolution spectra were recorded with a pass energy of 20 eV. The C1s contribution of sp2 carbon (“graphite”) at 284.6 eV was utilized to calibrate the energy axis. For deconvolution, Shirley background subtraction was conducted while pseudo-Voigt profiles were used for curve fitting (see the SI for a detailed fitting procedure)[45]. Combined in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) experiments were executed at beamline BM31 of the Swiss-Norwegian beamlines (SNBL) at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF) in Grenoble, France. A tubular quartz capillary reactor (1.5 mm internal diameter, 0.02 mm wall thickness) was loaded with ∼5 mg Co/CB and fixed with quartz wool plugs at each end of the catalyst bed (bed length 1 cm). The reactor was placed in a reaction setup, using mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst) to control the reaction atmosphere and a specifically developed resistance heater [46] to control the temperature. Off-gas analysis was conducted by online mass spectrometry (Pfeiffer Omnistar). XRD was executed using a Pilatus3 2 M detector (Dectris), utilizing monochromatic X-ray irradiation at λ = 0.24486 Å. Instrumental broadening, wavelength calibration as well as detector distance corrections were performed using a NIST 660a LaB6 standard. X-ray absorption spectroscopy was executed at the Co K edge (7709 eV) in transmission mode. Reduction experiments were conducted in a flow of 0.5 mL min−1 of 25 vol% H2 in He, heating from 50 to 350 °C at 10 °C min−1, while holding 350 °C for a maximum of 1 h, depending on the reducibility of the sample. During the reduction experiment, XANES profiles were recorded, while EXAFS and XRD was collected at 50 °C before and after the reduction, without any intermediate exposure to air. A Co0 hcp foil as well as CoO and Co3O4 powder served as standards, for which EXAFS data was measured ex situ in transmission mode. In addition, ex situ EXAFS was measured for the Co NP dispersion in toluene. Ex situ XRD reference data was collected for CB-H. XANES and EXAFS data were processed using the Athena and Artemis components of the Demeter package [47]. After normalization, linear combination fitting (LCF) of the XANES profiles was executed in the range from −20 eV to + 40 eV of the Co K-edge, with CoO and Co3O4 powder as well as Co/CB-H after reduction (for Co0) serving as standards. EXAFS analysis of the reduced Co/CB samples was conducted by first-shell fitting of k3 weighted data in R space in the range of 1 <R< 3 Å. The number of floating parameters used in the evaluation procedure satisfied the Nyquist criterion. For analysis of the XRD measurements, TOPAS 5.0 (Bruker) was used. Employing the NIST 660a LaB6 standard, emission profile as well as instrument details were determined. An ex situ measurement of the pristine support CB-H was used to approximate the support contribution by three Split Pearson VII profiles, which was subsequently used in the refinement of all further XRD measurements. During refinement of Co/CB catalyst samples, only scaling of the support pattern was allowed. The XRD patterns of the Co/CB catalyst samples were refined using database structures for Co hcp (COD-9008492), Co fcc (PDF-00–015–0806), CoO (COD-1541642) as well as Co3O4 (COD-9005896). For all Co phases, lattice expansion or reduction was restricted to ± 0.05 Å, signal broadening due to crystallite size effects was described by Lorentzian functions and strain broadening was excluded. Further refined was a Chebyshev background of 5th order, sample displacement, zero error, tilt and cylindrical 2 θ correction. In accordance with other literature procedures [19], due to the presence of a hcp-fcc intergrowth phase, we found that a sensible fit of the reduced catalysts was only obtainable by refinement of preferred orientation for the Co hcp (100) and (001) directions using the March-Dollase model. 2.5 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis FTS was carried out in a stainless-steel tubular reactor of 4 mm internal diameter. 100–200 mg Co/CB was diluted in a 1:4 g g−1 ratio by 400–800 mg of SiC and fixed between two glass wool plugs, with a type K thermocouple controlling the reactor temperature placed within the catalyst bed. Reduction of the catalysts was carried out in situ at atmospheric pressure by heating the reactor to 350 °C at a rate of 1 °C min−1 and holding for 8 h in a flow of 10 mL min−1 of 25 vol% H2 in Ar. After reduction, the reactor was cooled to 190 °C in a flow of 7.5 mL min−1 Ar and subsequently pressurized to 20 bar in an identical flow of Ar. Reaching 20 bar, synthesis gas was introduced with a H2:CO ratio of 2.1 and 10 vol% Ar as internal standard at a total flow rate of 5 mL min−1. Once the initial Ar atmosphere was replaced by syngas, the reactor was heated at 0.1 °C min−1 from 190 °C to 220 °C. After the end of each reaction run, spent catalysts were passivated at room temperature in a flow of 10 mL min−1 1 vol% O2 in Ar. Gaseous reaction products were analyzed by online gas chromatography using a GC-MS (Agilent GC7890B-MSD5977A) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) for detection and quantification of C2-C5 hydrocarbons, and a TCD for analysis of CH4, CO, H2 and Ar. Selectivities for C1-C4 in terms of %(C) were determined by SC1-C4 =  V ̇ Cn ∙ n ∙ ( V ̇ CO,in - V ̇ CO,out)−1, while the C5+ selectivity was calculated by SC5+ = 1 - SC1-C4. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Support functionalization Aiming to prepare carbon supports that exhibit similar O loading, but carbon surface oxide profiles that vary in composition, carbon black (CB) was functionalized by a sequence of an oxidation step in concentrated HNO3 and an annealing step in inert atmosphere. In this sequence, HNO3 oxidation introduces a wide variety of different O functional groups, while subsequent annealing is used to selectively remove specific surface oxides, exploiting well-known differences in thermal stability of O surface groups ( Scheme 1)[36,48]. In order to obtain carbon catalyst supports of similar oxygen weight loading, the oxidation temperature was balanced with the annealing temperature, as the amount of introduced surface oxides increases with oxidation temperature while an increasing annealing temperature removes an increasing amount of O functional groups (Fig. S1). Aiming to strike that balance, four different samples were prepared (designated CB-Toxidation-Tannealing) by oxidation alone (CB-70), and further by pairing increasing oxidation temperatures with increasing annealing temperatures (e.g. CB-95–330; CB-120–530 and CB-140–650). A non-functionalized reference support (CB-H) was prepared by annealing pristine CB at 950 °C in H2, attempting to remove any present surface oxides. The employed carbon support showed the hierarchical structure typical for carbon blacks, with primary particles of 20 – 40 nm in diameter forming stable aggregates of several 100 nm in size, which in turn form loose agglomerates ( Fig. 1a, b)[49]. It should be noted that the multiple black dots observable in brightfield STEM images correspond to regions of comparatively high crystallinity (Fig. 1b). The Raman ID/IG ratio was utilized as a descriptor for the structural order of the carbon black. The reference CB-H yielded a value of 1.27 ± 0.04, indicating a nanocrystalline carbon material with a low degree of long-range order (Fig. 1c, see Figs. S2a, b for further Raman characterization)[50,51]. Upon functionalization by oxidation/annealing, ID/IG ratios and consequently the (bulk-) structure remained largely unchanged for all produced catalyst supports. In contrast, the texture of the carbon black changed significantly, with increasing oxidation and annealing temperatures leading to an increase in specific surface area (SSA) from 114 m2 g−1 for CB-H to up to 426 m2 g−1 for CB-140–650 (Fig. 1c). While the general shape of the N2 physisorption isotherms did not change (isotherm type IVa), increasing oxidation/annealing temperatures caused a higher N2 uptake in the low relative pressure range 0<p/p0< 0.05, indicating the introduction of microporosity (Fig. 1d). Additional N2 uptake in the intermediate pressure range 0.1 <p/p0< 0.8 was only observed for CB-140–650, indicating the introduction of some additional mesoporosity (Fig. 1e)[52]. However, since the size of the colloidal Co nanoparticles used for catalyst synthesis (∼5.5 nm in the reduced state) exceeded the typical diameter of micropores (dpore < 2 nm) significantly, textural effects on catalyst performance such as pore confinement are not expected. The surface chemistry of the carbon black supports was probed by TPD-MS, TGA, elemental combustion analysis and XPS, with XPS survey spectra indicating that the surface of all samples is exclusively occupied by C and O species (Fig. S3). This finding is corroborated by elemental combustion analysis, which only found negligible amounts of heteroatoms such as N on the carbon black supports (Table S1). The combination of HNO3 oxidation and annealing in inert atmosphere introduced different surface oxide ensembles to the carbon black surface, as is clearly evident from the TPD CO2 and CO emission profiles of the different catalyst supports ( Fig. 2a, b). While the reference CB-H shows negligible CO2 desorption and only very little CO emission above 800 °C, HNO3 oxidation introduces a full range of surface oxides of different thermal stability as exemplified by the CO and CO2 emission profiles of CB-70. TPD CO and CO2 emission profiles show that if HNO3 oxidation is followed by annealing in inert atmosphere, surface oxides with decomposition temperatures below the annealing temperature are removed, resulting in a surface oxide ensemble composed of O functional groups of higher thermal stability. Integration of the CO, CO2 and H2O (chemisorbed H2O, emitted at T > 200 °C, only present in case of CB-70, (Figs. S4–6)) emission profiles yielded the O weight loading of the catalyst supports, which was found to be 0.1 wt% for the reference CB-H, while the O loading for the functionalized supports ranged between 2.2 and 2.8 wt% (Fig. 2c, see Table S2 for further analysis of O loading). As the specific surface area increased with harsher oxidation/annealing procedures, the similar O weight loadings of the carbon catalyst supports effectively resulted in significantly different O surface coverages, ranging from 0.5 O nm−2 for CB-H over 9.0 O nm−2 for CB-70–2.0 O nm−2 for CB-140–650 (Figs. 1c, 2c). Quantification of individual surface oxides was achieved by deconvolution of the TPD CO2, CO and H2O emission profiles (Fig. 2d, e and S4–6). In this context, CB-70 shows the broadest range of different O functional groups, including carboxylic acids, anhydrides and lactones as CO2 emitting groups and alcohols, phenols, carbonyls/ethers as well as quinones functional groups decomposing to CO. CB-70 was also the sample with the highest CO2/CO ratio of 0.59, indicating a comparatively acidic surface, as CO2 emission is directly linked to the presence of carboxylic acid derivates, while the majority of CO emitting groups are neutral or weakly basic (Table S2)[38]. CB-70 was the only sample that emitted significant amounts of chemisorbed H2O, which is a known indicator for temperature induced condensation reactions, such as the condensation of two adjacent carboxylic acid groups to form an anhydride (Fig. S6)[48]. Detection of chemisorbed H2O thus leads to an underestimation of the concentration of carboxylic acid groups, and an overestimation of the amount of carboxylic anhydrides. Previous studies indicated that a more realistic estimate of the concentration of carboxylic acids and carboxylic anhydrides may be reached by subtracting the amount of chemisorbed H2O from the concentration of carboxylic anhydrides, while adding it to the concentration of carboxylic acids[44]. Following this procedure yields a carboxylic acid concentration of 296 μmol g−1, illustrating the high concentration of acidic surface groups of CB-70. Annealing at 330 °C leads to an almost complete removal of carboxylic acids (Tdecomposition: ∼300 °C [48]) in case of CB-95–330, with the remaining CO2 emitting groups being carboxylic anhydrides and lactones. Residual CO2 emission in the temperature range of carboxylic acid decomposition observed for CB-95–330 (but also for CB-120–530 and CB-140–650) is most likely a consequence of (re-)adsorption of oxygen containing species (e. g. O2, CO2, H2O) after exposing the sample to ambient air after the heat treatment in inert atmosphere. In case of CO emitting surface oxides, annealing at 330 °C leads to the decomposition of alcohols, with phenols, carbonyls/ethers and quinones remaining on the surface. Decomposition of the carboxylic acids causes a significant decrease in the CO2/CO ratio to 0.21, while the absence of chemisorbed H2O indicates that the TPD quantification is not distorted by condensation reactions (Table S2). Further annealing at 530 °C (CB-120–530) decreases the CO2/CO ratio to 0.13, as in addition to carboxylic acids and alcohols also carboxylic anhydrides (Tdecomposition: ∼450 °C) as well as phenols (Tdecomposition: ∼500 °C) are removed (Fig. 2d, e and Table S2)[48]. The resulting carbon surface was thus found to be occupied by lactones, carbonyls/ethers and quinones. Annealing at 650 °C (CB-140–650) further decomposed part of the lactones (Tdecomposition: ∼650 °C) as well as the carbonyl/ethers (Tdecomposition: ∼650 °C), leading to a carbon surface solely occupied by lactones and quinones (CO2/CO ratio 0.16, Fig. 2d, e and Table S2)[48]. Analysis of the XPS C 1 s contribution generally reflects the trends found in TPD analysis, such as the lower amount of C-O and O-CO surface species and an increase in CO species with increasing annealing temperature (Figs. S8, S9). However, as XPS can only distinguish between certain groups of carbon surface oxides, XPS and TPD quantification are not directly comparable[48]. 3.2 Catalyst preparation Co NP were synthesized by thermal decomposition of Co2(CO)8 in presence of oleic acid as ligand and subsequently exposed to air, yielding cobalt oxide nanoparticles of a mean diameter of 7.1 ± 0.7 nm as determined by STEM imaging ( Fig. 3a, b)[41,53]. This specific Co NP synthesis method was chosen as it is comparatively well-established for the preparation of Co-based FTS catalysts[8,19,41,54–56] and was shown to provide intrinsic activities comparable to catalysts prepared by conventional methods (e. g. incipient wetness impregnation)[8]. For better comparability, particle diameters will be reported for metallic Co in the following, corrected for a 3 nm cobalt oxide layer. Subsequently, the Co NP’s were attached to the carbon black catalyst supports, aiming for a Co weight loading of ∼7 wt% ( Table 1). Wet impregnation achieved a uniform distribution of the Co NP’s on the supports, without any significant change in shape, clustering and/or change in particle size distribution (Fig. 3c, see Figs. S10 and S11 for STEM images and Co particle size distributions of all Co/CB catalysts). It should be noted that for a spherical Co0 nanoparticle with a 5.6 nm diameter (Table 1), only ∼18 % of the total Co atoms are surface atoms, while the support surface exhibits significant curvature and in case of high oxidation temperatures, also substantial surface roughness. In this context, only a small fraction of Co atoms of each NP is expected to be in direct contact with the carbon support. XANES-LCF analysis of the CB-supported Co NP’s revealed a composition of 73–86 at% CoO, 14–24 at% Co3O4 and minor amounts of metallic cobalt (Table 1, Fig. S12). XRD analysis showed that the crystalline CoO domains (2.8 – 3.2 nm) were significantly smaller than the mean particle diameter, indicating that the Co NP’s consisted of multiple crystalline domains, which compares well with literature (Table 1, Fig. S13)[19,41]. It should be noted in this context, that STEM-derived Co particle sizes refer to the actual size of the Co nanoparticles, while XRD results refer strictly to the size of crystalline domains. 3.3 Catalyst reduction Catalyst reduction was examined by TPR and in situ XANES ( Fig. 4). During TPR, all catalysts showed comparatively sharp H2 uptake signals between 290 and 398 °C that can be related to CoO reduction. In addition, Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 show a second, broad contribution centered around 600 °C that could be assigned to Co catalyzed carbon hydrogenation [19]. The sharp H2 uptake signals related to Co reduction compared well to the observation that the Co NP’s were composed predominantly of CoO, with reduction to Co0 thus occurring in a single step (Table 1). The reduction temperature was clearly dependent on the presence or absence of O functional groups on the support, as Co reduction for Co/CB-95–330 (379 °C), Co/CB-120–530 (398 °C) and Co/CB-140–650 (390 °C) occurred 89–108 °C above the reduction of the non-functionalized reference Co/CB-H (290 °C). A notable exception to this observation was Co/CB-70, showing a comparable reduction temperature (301 °C) to Co/CB-H (Fig. 4a). The reduction behavior of the different catalysts was further investigated by in situ XAS at the Co K edge, using XANES to follow the Co phase composition and online mass spectrometry for off-gas analysis (Fig. 4b, c and S14). In this case, Co reduction was carried out by heating the catalysts (10 °C min−1) to 350 °C and holding this temperature for up to 1 h in a flow H2 in He. It should be noted that reduction conditions before the actual FTS experiments (1 °C min, 8 h hold at 350 °C) deviated from the conditions used in the in situ experiments, meaning that the properties of the catalysts after the in situ XAS experiments (such as the degree of reduction (DOR)), might only be a close, but not exact representation of the state of the catalysts before FTS testing. Reduction of the supported Co NP’s followed the well-known two-step mechanism, with the first reduction of Co3O4 to CoO proceeding in a temperature range between 180 and 270 °C for all catalysts (Fig. 4b and S14). The second reduction step of CoO to Co0 started to accelerate around 300 °C for all materials, with CoO reduction proceeding rapidly in case of Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70, achieving a DOR of 1 almost immediately after the plateau at 350 °C was reached (Fig. 4b, c and S14). The reduction of CoO to Co0 proceeded considerably slower for the other catalysts, reaching DOR’s of 0.83 for Co/CB-95–330, 0.75 for Co/CB-120–530 and 0.79 for Co/CB-140–650 after one hour of reduction at 350 °C. Considering the decreasing rate of reduction while holding 350 °C, it appears unlikely that Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 reach significantly higher DOR’s by extending the holding time at 350 °C·H2O (m/Z 18) emission as a complementary indicator for the Co reduction rate matched the XANES-LCF analysis well, with Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70 showing sharp peaks due to a high rate of Co reduction, while H2O emission signals for the other catalysts were significantly broader (Fig. 4c). The observed differences in reducibility between the reference Co/CB-H and Co supported on O functionalized carbon black may be assigned to increased metal/support interactions in presence of carbon support oxides. A lower Co reducibility on oxidized carbon supports has been reported before, putting the reduction behavior of Co/CB-H, Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 well in line with literature[19]. An exception to this finding is Co/CB-70, which is highly reducible despite exhibiting the highest O surface coverage of all carbon black supports. In this context, the main difference between CB-70 and the other oxidized supports is its high surface concentration of thermally labile carboxylic acids (Tdecomposition ∼300 °C [48]), which are not present on the other oxidized supports and are expected to decompose during reduction at 350 °C. Decarboxylation of carboxylic acids during reduction of Co/CB-70 would alter the cobalt/carbon interface considerably, decreasing the O surface coverage by 17 % from 9.0 O nm−2 to 7.5 O nm−2. Decomposition of carbon surface oxides to CO/CO2 is known to yield reactive, unsaturated carbon surface sites (“dangling bonds”), that are highly susceptible to chemisorption and might be involved in cobalt/carbon interactions [57]. We thus hypothesize, that the high reducibility of Co/CB-70 is a consequence of the decomposition of thermally labile carboxylic acids and the accompanied changes of the carbon/cobalt interface, facilitating direct interactions between cobalt and carbon, without intermediate oxygen species. In this context, the decomposition of carbon surface oxides was probed by monitoring CO2 (m/Z 44) emission during reduction, showing that CO2 emission occurred for all catalysts (Fig. 4c). Above 300 °C (>25 min), CO2 emission can be assigned to the decomposition of residual oleic acid ligands on the Co NP’s, which is known to coincide with the reduction of CoO to Co0 and yields sharp CO2 emission maxima for all catalysts [41]. Oleic acid decomposition coinciding with CoO reduction above 300 °C could be confirmed by the characteristic profile of m/Z 15 which corresponds to CH3 +, a fragment associated with oleic acid decomposition (Fig. S15, see Sidenote S1 on oleic acid ligands for a detailed discussion). However, CO2 emission was also observed below this temperature, whereas all O functionalized supports show a significantly higher CO2 development compared to the non-functionalized reference Co/CB-H. This finding indicates that decomposition of carbon surface oxides during reduction may play a role on all catalysts, despite the presence of increasingly temperature stable surface oxide ensembles on Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650. However, CO2 emission of Co/CB-70 is significantly higher compared to the other catalysts supported on O functionalized carbon black, hinting that the decarboxylation of thermally labile carboxylic acids leads to significant changes in the O surface oxide ensemble during reduction. Overall, TPR and in situ XANES experiments suggest that COOH decomposition during reduction leads to Co nanoparticles on CB-70 that are in close contact with the carbon surface, resulting in a reducibility similar to Co NP’s on the non-functionalized CB-H. In contrast, Co nanoparticles on CB-95–330, CB-120–530, and CB-140–650 likely interact with temperature-stable surface oxides, such as alcohol or carbonyl groups, reducing their overall reducibility. 3.4 Reduced catalysts As Co0 is the active species for FTS, the characterization of the reduced catalysts is crucial for the interpretation of catalyst performance data. To this end, the reduced catalysts were characterized by HAADF-STEM imaging ( Fig. 5 and S16), as well as by in situ XRD and in situ EXAFS ( Fig. 6 and S17- S19). It should be noted that STEM imaging was carried out after reduction (1 °C min−1 to 350 °C, 8 h hold, 25 vol% H2), passivation and air exposure, while EXAFS and XRD were conducted in situ without air exposure after the in situ XANES reduction experiments (10 °C min−1 to 350 °C, 1 h hold, 25 vol% H2) discussed in the previous section. While STEM imaging showed an increase in average Co particle diameters after reduction for all Co/CB catalysts, the extent of Co particle growth was found to vary widely (Fig. 5, 6a and S11, S16). Co particles grew from 5.5 to 6.3 nm (+14 %) for Co/CB-70, while reduction of Co/CB-H induced an increase of the average Co particle diameter of + 108 %, as particles grew from 5.6 to 11.7 nm. Co particle growth was found to be inversely proportional to the O surface coverage of the supports, as it followed the sequence Co/CB-H > Co/CB-140–650 > Co/CB-120–530 > Co/CB-95–330 > Co/CB-70 (Fig. 6a and S11). In situ XRD of the reduced catalysts clearly showed the presence of crystalline Co0 in both hcp and fcc phase for all catalysts, while residual CoO was detected in case of Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 (Fig. 6b and S17, Table S3). Rietveld refinement assuming crystal polymorphism in terms of a mixture of Co hcp/fcc phases was found to yield inadequate refinement results, most likely due to the presence of a Co hcp/fcc intergrowth phase, which is known to form by reduction of supported cobalt oxide nanoparticles [19,58,59]. Indeed, the observed diffraction patterns match well with simulated XRD’s of Co nanoparticles of 5 – 10 nm diameter featuring an Co hcp/fcc intergrowth structure as calculated by Sławiński et al. [58] A refinement procedure by van Deelen et al. was adapted to obtain better refinement results, relying on the introduction of preferred orientations for Co hcp crystallites [19]. Even though physically disputable, this assumption enables to reproduce most of the features of the Co hcp/fcc intergrowth structure, however at the price of a higher uncertainty of the obtained refinement results (Fig. S17). The Co phase composition obtained from Rietveld refinement matched the in situ XANES LCF analysis well, indicating full reduction for Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70, while remaining CoO was detected in case of the partly reduced CB-95–330 (17 wt%), CB-120–530 (25 wt%) and CB-140–650 (20 wt%, see Table S3). The composition of the Co0 phase varied widely, with Co hcp/fcc ratios ranging from 0.15 (Co/CB-70) up to 3.6 (Co/CB-95–330, see Table S3). In terms of crystallite size, it was found that the Co hcp domains were generally significantly smaller than the average particle size determined from STEM imaging, which was previously assigned to be an artefact caused by the assumption of preferred crystallite orientation for Co hcp [19]. For Co fcc, crystallite sizes in the range of the STEM particle sizes were found for Co/CB-H (13.5 nm) and Co/CB-70 (5.8 nm), while refinement of the diffraction patterns of Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 yielded crystallite sizes well below the STEM particle size for both Co hcp and fcc phases (Table S3). In this sense, it might be concluded that Co particles on Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70 were monocrystalline, while Co NP’s on Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 were polycrystalline, although this conclusion lacks certainty due to the limitations of the applied Rietveld refinement procedure for the Co hcp/fcc intergrowth structure. In their study of diffraction patterns of Co NP’s of different structures and sizes, Sławiński et al. note that the (overlapping) Co0 (110)hcp/(022)fcc peak around 11.2 ° / 2 θ is not affected by the stacking disorder induced by intergrowth and might thus be used for an FWHM-based evaluation of Co crystallite size (e. g. following the Scherrer equation)[58]. Here, a relative comparison of Co crystallite size is carried out, utilizing the full width at half-maximum (FWHM), which is inversely proportional to the Co crystallite size (Fig. 6c and S17f, Table S3). The FWHM of the (110)hcp/(022)fcc peak after catalyst reduction was found to be 0.11 ° / 2 θ for Co/CB-H and 0.15 ° / 2 θ for Co/CB-70, indicating a larger crystallite size for Co/CB-H as compared to Co/CB-70. This finding compares well with the differences in Co0 particle diameter after catalyst reduction as observed by STEM imaging (11.7 nm for Co/CB-H vs. 6.3 nm for Co/CB-70). However, larger FWHM’s are detected for Co/CB-95–330 (0.17 ° / 2 θ), Co/CB-120–530 (0.21 ° / 2 θ) and Co/CB-140–650 (0.21 ° / 2 θ) suggesting smaller Co crystallites as compared to Co/CB-70, even though STEM imaging after reduction clearly showed larger mean Co0 particle diameters for those catalysts than for Co/CB-70 (Fig. 6c). This analysis thus supports the hypothesis that reduced Co NP’s were likely to be polycrystalline in case of Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650, while those in case of Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70 were monocrystalline. In order to further investigate the local structure of the Co NP’s of the reduced catalysts, in situ EXAFS measurements were carried out (Fig. 6d, e). Fitting of the first coordination shell yielded no significant bond length deviation compared to a bulk Co hcp standard, as the length of the Co0 – Co0 scattering path did not deviate by more than ± 0.01 Å of the reference, which is well within the expected accuracy of ± 0.02 Å (Fig. 6f and S18–19, Table S4). However, the first shell coordination number of some of the reduced Co/CB catalysts deviated significantly from that of the Co0 foil reference (CN = 12 for first coordination shell for both bulk fcc and hcp Co), ranging from 11.4 for Co/CB-H to 9.5 for Co/CB-140–650 (Fig. 6f, Table S4). Considering that the uncertainty of the determination of the first-shell CN is typically around ± 10 %, at least Co/CB-H (CN 11.4) and Co/CB-70 (CN 11.1) exhibited Co0 coordination numbers that are identical with bulk Co within the range of error. Given the Co0 particle sizes of the reduced samples determined by STEM imaging (11.7 nm for Co/CB-H, 6.3 nm for Co/CB-70) this result is expected, as significant particle size related decreases in CN are only to be expected for spherical NP’s < 5 nm [60,61]. However, first shell Co0 coordination numbers further decline for Co/CB-95–330 (CN 10.3), Co/CB-120–530 (CN 10.2) and Co/CB-140–650 (CN 9.5) in an obvious mismatch with the corresponding Co0 particle sizes as determined by STEM imaging, which increase from 6.7 nm for Co/CB-95–330 over 7.5 nm for Co/CB-120–530–8.2 nm for Co/CB-140–650 (Fig. 6a, f). This mismatch between Co0 NP size and CN was encountered before in context of supported Co FTS catalysts [62–65], and has been assigned to surface disorder [66] (deviations from the ideal crystal structure at the surface of NP’s as induced for example by surface tension) or structural disorder as induced by polycrystallinity [63]. In the latter case, first-shell Co0 CN’s would reflect the domain size of the ensemble of smaller crystallites constituting a Co NP, whereas Co particle size as determined by STEM imaging accounts for the total size of the Co NP [63]. In any case, both in situ EXAFS as well as in situ XRD suggest differences in the structure of the Co NP’s in the reduced state, as Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70 appear to display a more ordered, monocrystalline structure, while Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 seem to exhibit a more disordered, polycrystalline structure. 3.5 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis After reduction at 350 °C for 8 h, the Co/CB catalysts were subjected to FTS for 115 h time on stream at 20 bar and a syngas ratio (H2:CO) of 2.1 ( Fig. 7 and S20, Table 2). In order to probe catalyst stability, temperature was initially kept at 220 °C for 80 h, but was subsequently increased to 230 °C and 240 °C for 15 h each, before being returned to 220 °C. The activity of the catalysts was evaluated as CO consumption normalized to the cobalt mass (designated as cobalt time yield, CTY), with Co/CB catalysts displaying widely different activities. Initial Co mass-based activity was found to be highest for Co/CB-H (9.0 · 10−5 molCO gCo −1 s−1), while Co/CB-120–530 showed the lowest initial activity at (1.6 · 10−5 molCO gCo −1 s−1) (Fig. 7, Table 2). Likewise, initial C5+ selectivity was highest over Co/CB-H (87 % C5+), and lowest over Co/CB-120–530 (46 % C5+), however, due to the different degrees of conversion (59 % and 21 %, respectively) those selectivities are not directly comparable (Fig. S20, Table 2). Comparison of C5+ selectivities of Co/CB-H (87 % C5+), Co/CB-70 (69 % C5+) and Co/CB-95–330 (69 % C5+) could be obtained at similar degrees of conversion, indicating that the presence of carbon surface oxides lead to lower C5+ selectivities, which is in line with literature reports[19,24]. Over the first 50 h TOS, catalyst deactivation was clearly evident for all Co/CB catalysts, with stabilization at a pseudo steady state only occurring towards 80 h TOS (Fig. 7). The subsequent temperature steps to 230 and 240 °C led to a further decay of catalyst activity, as none of the catalysts was able to return to the same level of activity when the temperature was lowered back to 220 °C. At 115 h TOS and after completion of the temperature steps, CTY values had decreased by 71 % for Co/CB-H and by 80 – 84 % for the Co NP’s supported on O functionalized carbon black (Table 2). These results are qualitatively in line with literature reports comparing Co supported on HNO3 oxidized and non-functionalized carbon (comparable to Co/CB-70 and Co/CB-H of this study, respectively), which also observed a lower activity and more pronounced deactivation on the oxidized carbon support as opposed to the non-functionalized support [19]. After passivation, the spent catalysts were characterized for their particle size distribution by STEM imaging (Fig. 5, 6a and S11, S21). The average Co0 particle size increased over 115 h FTS for all catalysts, however, to a very different extent. While particles grew by an additional 10 % (from 6.3 after reduction to 6.9 nm after FTS) over Co/CB-70, the average diameter of Co0 NP’s increased by 76 % (from 6.7 after reduction to 11.8 nm after FTS) for Co/CB-95–330 (Fig. 6a). Over the whole catalyst reduction and FTS cycle, Co particle growth was found to be most severe on Co/CB-H (growing from 5.6 to 11.7 after reduction to 15.1 nm after FTS), while Co/CB-70 showed the lowest sintering tendency (growing from 5.5 to 6.3 after reduction to 6.9 nm after FTS) (Fig. 5, 6a, S11). The average Co0 particle diameters of the reduced and spent catalysts obtained by STEM were used to calculate intrinsic activities in form of the initial and final site time yield (STY, Table 2). In this context, Co/CB-H displayed the by far highest initial STY with 62 · 10−3 s−1, with Co/CB-120–530 exhibiting the lowest at 7 · 10−3 s−1, whereas the difference in STY of Co supported on non-functionalized and O functionalized carbon is qualitatively in line with literature reports[19,24]. Comparison of initial and final STY shows a significant decline for all catalysts, as 62–81 % of the initial intrinsic activity are lost over 115 h FTS (Table 2). It is worth to note that again the non-functionalized catalyst Co/CB-H showed the least amount of intrinsic deactivation (STY −62 %), while Co supported on oxidized carbon lost between 72 % and 81 % of its initial STY. This decrease in intrinsic activities indicates that besides Co particle growth also other deactivation mechanisms are at work for all catalysts, with Co re-oxidation [27] and deactivation by deposition of carbonaceous species [19] among others, being conceivable. 3.6 Composition effects of the carbon surface oxide ensemble It should be noted that establishing a precise correlation between the effects of carbon surface oxides and the stability and performance of the catalyst is highly challenging, mostly due to the lack of options for in situ characterization of carbon surface oxides, leaving the exact composition of the carbon surface oxide ensemble during the reaction unresolved. In addition, post-mortem analysis of carbon surface oxides in Co/C FTS catalysts presents significant difficulties as the presence of waxes that are difficult to remove completely, combined with the presence of cobalt species, severely impedes the application of conventional analytical methods (e.g., XPS and TPD). With these limitations in mind, the following discussion focuses on the correlations between the carbon surface oxides present before the reaction and the catalytic performance. One of the main reasons for the interest in surface oxidized carbon supports in context of Co-based FTS catalysts was the desire to improve Co NP anchoring and thus impede the loss of active Co surface area by sintering [19,24]. The present study clearly shows that Co NP sintering can be effectively suppressed by surface oxidation of the carbon support, as demonstrated by an increase of Co particle size by 170 % on the non-functionalized support over the studied cycle of catalyst activation and FTS, as opposed to only 25 % on oxidized carbon black (Co/CB-70, see Fig. 6a and Fig. 8a). In this context, cobalt particle growth appears to be independent of the composition of the carbon surface oxide ensemble, as it shows a close correlation to the O surface coverage of the carbon support, with higher oxygen coverages impeding Co NP growth more effectively (Fig. 8a). It should be noted that the O surface coverage of Co/CB-70 is expected to decrease during catalyst reduction, due to the decomposition of thermally labile carboxylic acid groups. However, it is known that the decomposition/desorption of carbon surface oxides yields highly reactive carbon surface sites [48,57], meaning that the overall amount of surface sites available for Co NP anchoring may not decrease significantly. As a consequence, Co NP growth during FTS remained low on Co/CB-70 (+ 10 %) as compared to Co/CB-95–330 (+ 77 %), Co/CB-120–530 (+ 57 %) and Co/CB-140–650 (+ 66 %) even though part of the surface oxide ensemble decomposed during reduction. As opposed to the sintering tendency, the reducibility of Co NP’s was found to be dependent on the composition of the carbon surface ensemble (Fig. 8b). In this context, Co on the carbon support with the highest O surface coverage (Co/CB-70) was proven to be easily reducible, while Co on the other O functionalized supports, such as Co/CB-95–330 reached only DOR’s in the range of 0.8 and showed TPR reduction rate maxima located at up to 97 °C higher temperatures. Comparison of Co/CB-70 and Co/CB-95–330 is interesting, as the annealing at 330 °C after oxidation removes carboxylic acid groups with a high degree of selectivity, meaning that the most significant difference in the surface oxide profiles of Co/CB-70 and Co/CB-95–330 is the presence or absence of carboxylic acids. Co/CB-70 with carboxylic acid groups present on the support surface reaches a DOR of 1, while Co/CB-95–330 only reaches a DOR of 0.83. We hypothesize that this observation is connected to the thermal decomposition of carboxylic acids during reduction, with the accompanying changes of the carbon/cobalt interface giving rise to direct cobalt/carbon interactions without intermediate O species and thus to a higher reducibility. Despite a lower O surface coverage as compared to Co/CB-95–330, Co reducibility further decreases for Co/CB-120–530 (DOR 0.75), with the main difference in the carbon surface oxide ensemble being the absence of acidic carboxylic anhydrides and phenolic OH groups, with basic carbonyl groups and quinones being the dominant surface species on Co/CB-120–530. While the ratio of acidic carboxylic acid derivates and more basic carbonyls/quinones stayed roughly the same, the decrease in O surface coverage might be responsible for the slightly improved reducibility of Co/CB-140–650 (DOR 0.79, Fig. 8b). Generally, these results indicate that acidic O surface groups enable higher Co reducibility as opposed to basic surface oxides, suggesting differences in the ability of carboxylic acid derivates on one hand, and carbonyls/quinones on the other to stabilize cobalt oxides. In terms of activity, the differences between Co supported on oxidized and non-functionalized carbon are significant and appear to depend on the composition of the support surface oxide profile. Co supported on the oxidized carbon supports showed significantly lower CTY’s as compared to Co on the non-functionalized support, despite a more favorable Co particle size on the oxidized supports (Fig. 6a, Table 2). Qualitatively, the intrinsic activity of the catalysts follows the trend in reducibility, with Co/CB-H exhibiting the highest reducibility as well as STY and Co/CB-120–530 the lowest. However, Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70 both reach complete reduction (DOR ∼1), while Co/CB-H displays a STY which is a factor of 2.5 higher, clearly indicating that additional factors are at play. As there is evidence for a higher FTS activity of the Co hcp over the Co fcc polymorph, also differences in the hcp/fcc ratio might play a role in the observed activity differences [59,67,68]. Rietveld analysis of the XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts did indeed yield differences in Co hcp/fcc ratio (Table S3), however the presence of a complex Co hcp/fcc intergrowth structure on all catalysts resulted in a high uncertainty of the determined ratios and thus in little informative value for the discussion of catalyst activity [58]. Another factor that may contribute to the difference in initial STY between Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70 are non-classical cobalt particle size effects. After reduction, the average Co particle diameter is 11.7 ± 6.4 nm for Co/CB-H and 6.3 ± 1.0 nm for Co/CB-70. The cobalt nanoparticle size below which a significant drop in STY is expected is reported to be 6 nm [11,24,31] and/or 6–8 nm [30], depending on the reaction conditions [30]. In this context, the mean Co nanoparticle size of Co/CB-70 is close to this threshold, making particle size effects conceivable. However, it is important to note that the size distribution of Co/CB-70 is relatively narrow, meaning the fraction of Co particles significantly smaller than the 6 nm threshold (e. g. < 5 nm) is negligible. Comparison of the Co crystallite size to Co particle size and to the Co0 coordination number indicated structural differences of the reduced Co NP supported on different carbon supports. While in case of Co/CB-H and Co/CB-70 Co NP’s seemed to display monocrystallinity and a lower degree of disorder, NP’s on Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 were found to exhibit local disorder and a polycrystalline microstructure. In this context, Tsakoumis et al. were able to link structural faults on γ-Al2O3 supported Co FTS catalysts to lower intrinsic activities and C5+ selectivity, with defect-free Co hcp surfaces being most favorable in terms of FTS performance [59]. In situ XRD studies by van Deelen et al. on a similar catalyst system (Co NP attached to oxidized and non-functional CNT’s) [19] showed that the crystal structure of the reduced catalysts remained unchanged upon exposure to FTS conditions, indicating that the differences in Co NP microstructure found in the reduced catalyst in this study are representative also for the Co structure under FTS conditions. As such, differences in the crystal structure of Co NP’s may be a part of the explanation of the significantly lower STY’s as well as C5+ selectivities observed on Co/CB-95–330 (STY 16 · 10−3 s−1), Co/CB-120–530 (STY 7 · 10−3 s−1) and Co/CB-140–650 (STY 11 · 10−3 s−1) as compared to Co/CB-H (STY 62 · 10−3 s−1). The fact that Co/CB-70 exhibits the highest surface oxygen coverage (9 O nm−2, or 7.5 O nm−2 if it is assumed that carboxylic acid groups decompose during catalyst reduction) but shows ordered, monocrystalline Co NP’s after reduction, suggests that the composition of the carbon surface oxide ensemble plays a role in this case as well. It should be noted that Co NP’s on Co/CB-95–330, Co/CB-120–530 and Co/CB-140–650 also contain ∼20 % CoO, which may influence the crystal structure of the reduced Co0 phase. The connection between the carbon surface oxide ensemble and the Co0 crystal structure might thus only be indirect, with basic surface oxides such as carbonyls and quinones stabilizing the CoO phase, which in turn influences the crystal structure of the Co0 fraction formed during reduction. In summary, variations in intrinsic FTS activity cannot be attributed to a single structural difference but are most likely the result of a combination of factors, including the degree of reduction, the cobalt crystal phase, and the defectivity of cobalt nanoparticles. These factors, in turn, seem to be strongly influenced by the presence and composition of carbon surface oxides. 4 Conclusion In this study, the effects of various carbon surface oxide ensembles on activity and stability of carbon-supported, Co-based FTS catalysts were investigated by combining selectively functionalized carbon model supports with colloidal Co nanoparticles of narrow size distribution. Surface oxidation of carbon supports effectively suppressed the sintering of Co NPs during catalyst reduction and FTS. However, Co particle growth was primarily correlated with the oxygen surface coverage of the support, as higher oxygen coverages resulted in better prevention of Co NP growth, regardless of the type of carbon surface oxide ensemble. In contrast, cobalt reducibility and FTS activity of the catalysts were both strongly influenced by the composition of surface oxides on the carbon supports. Supports dominated by basic surface oxides, such as carbonyls and quinones, significantly hindered Co reduction, resulting ultimately in lower catalyst activity. On the other hand, supports rich in carboxylic acid groups promoted a higher degree of Co reduction, leading to higher FTS activity. Furthermore, it was found that Co on carbonyl/quinone-rich supports reduces into a disordered, polycrystalline metal phase, unlike the monocrystalline phase formed on carboxylic acid-rich supports, with structural disorder being associated with lower catalytic performance. Despite the stabilizing effects of oxidized carbon supports in preventing Co NP sintering, Co on the non-functionalized reference support demonstrated superior overall FTS performance in terms of activity, selectivity for C5+ hydrocarbons, and resistance to deactivation. In conclusion, although introducing carbon surface oxides effectively prevents cobalt nanoparticle growth, it negatively impacts catalyst activity and overall performance. These findings challenge existing design strategies for Co/C catalysts, suggesting that stability improvements must be carefully balanced against their impact on catalytic performance. In this context, alternative strategies such as heteroatom doping or pore confinement may provide more promising solutions for the development of deactivation-resistant, carbon-supported Co-based FTS catalysts. XRD, EXAFS, STEM micrographs and Co particle size distributions of the pristine Co/CB catalysts. Results and analysis of in situ XRD and in situ EXAFS, as well as STEM-HAADF micrographs and Co particle size distributions of the reduced Co/CB catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Carbon catalyst supports offer an attractive alternative to traditional oxidic supports for Co-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts, however, weak metal/carbon interactions facilitate catalyst deactivation by cobalt nanoparticle sintering. In this study we investigated the introduction of carbon surface oxides to mitigate cobalt sintering, combining carbon model supports featuring various surface oxide profiles with size-defined, colloidal Co nanoparticles. Carbon surface oxidation was found to effectively suppress cobalt nanoparticle sintering. Employing in situ XRD and XAS, we could show that Co supported on carbon featuring surface carbonyls/quinones displays low reducibility and forms disordered, polycrystalline Co0 nanoparticles, which are associated with poor FTS performance. In contrast, Co on supports occupied by carboxylic acids were easily reducible and formed monocrystalline nanoparticles enabling comparatively high FTS activities. However, despite effectively suppressing Co nanoparticle sintering, carbon surface oxidation was proven detrimental for FTS performance, as Co supported on non-functionalized carbon outperformed all catalysts on oxidized supports.
